newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi to lessen dependence on oil revenues.
newsitem.headline: Saudi to lessen dependence on oil revenues.

text.p: Saudi Arabia will continue policies to help diversify its economy and cut reliance on oil revenue, Saudi Minister of Finance and National Economy Ibrahim Abdul-Aziz al-Asaf said in remarks published on Friday.
"No doubt, oil will continue to play an important role in the Saudi economy," he told an Arab capital markets conference in Beirut on Thursday.
"But at the same time, we notice that as time passes and a non-oil sector is growing up, this role is diminishing," Asaf said. His remarks were carried by the Saudi Gazette newspaper.

He said oil revenues, which amounted to 58 percent of Saudi gross domestic product (GDP) in 1974, dropped to 30 percent in 1995 after Riyadh began market-oriented policies to boost industrial production and give the private sector a bigger role in the economy.
The world's largest oil producer has always been vulnerable to the uncertainties of international oil prices.
